BooseApp

me: Hi have a .net c# project i want to make a docsite for using docfx whats the commands i need for this any any changes to files ChatGPT: Below is a clear, minimal set of steps and commands to create a DocFX documentation site for a .NET C# project, including what files you need to add or modify.

‚úÖ 1. Install DocFX

If you don‚Äôt already have DocFX installed:

Option 1 ‚Äî .NET tool (recommended for DocFX 2.70+)

dotnet tool update -g docfx

Option 2 ‚Äî Chocolatey

choco install docfx -y

‚úÖ 2. Create a DocFX project

Navigate to your solution root:

cd YourSolution/
docfx init -q

This creates a docfx_project folder containing:

  • docfx.json ‚Äî main configuration file
  • api/ ‚Äî API documentation placeholder
  • articles/ ‚Äî pages for guides and tutorials
  • index.md ‚Äî homepage

‚úÖ 3. Generate API Documentation from Your C# Code

Inside docfx.json, make sure the metadata section points to your project or solution:

Example for a solution:

"metadata": [
  {
    "src": [
      { "files": [ "**/*.csproj" ], "cwd": "../" }
    ],
    "dest": "api"
  }
]

Example for a single project:

"metadata": [
  {
    "src": [
      { "files": [ "YourProject.csproj" ] }
    ],
    "dest": "api"
  }
]

‚úÖ 4. Add XML documentation output to your C# project

DocFX reads the XML comments from your code.

Edit your .csproj to include:

<PropertyGroup>
  <GenerateDocumentationFile>true</GenerateDocumentationFile>
  <NoWarn>1591</NoWarn>
</PropertyGroup>

‚úÖ 5. Build metadata (API docs)

From inside the docfx project folder:

docfx metadata

DocFX will scan your C# code and generate YAML files under /api.

‚úÖ 6. Build the full documentation site

docfx build

This generates your static site under _site.

‚úÖ 7. Preview the documentation locally

docfx serve _site

Open:

http://localhost:8080

üìÅ Summary of File Changes

File What to change
YourProject.csproj Add XML doc generation block
docfx.json Update metadata ‚Üí src to point to .csproj or .sln
articles/*.md Write your guides/tutorials
index.md Edit your docsite homepage

‚≠ê Typical Folder Structure After Setup

YourSolution/
 ‚îú‚îÄ src/
 ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ YourProject.csproj
 ‚îú‚îÄ docfx_project/
 ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ api/
 ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ articles/
 ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ index.md
 ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ docfx.json
 ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ _site/ (generated)

If you want, I can also generate a ready-to-use docfx.json for your exact project structure‚Äîjust tell me what your folders are called.

me: PS C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL> docfx metadata FileNotFoundException: Cannot find config file C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\docfx.json at (DocfxConfig , string configDirectory) GetConfig(string configFile) in Docset.cs:73 at void b__0() in MetadataCommand.cs:16 at int Run(LogOptions options, Action run) in CommandHelper.cs:48 at int Execute(CommandContext context, MetadataCommandOptions options) in MetadataCommand.cs:14 at Task Execute(CommandContext context, CommandSettings settings) in CommandOfT.cs:40 at async Task Execute(CommandTree leaf, CommandTree tree, CommandContext context, ITypeResolver resolver, IConfiguration configuration) in CommandExecutor.cs:259 ChatGPT: Ah! That error is actually very clear:

FileNotFoundException: Cannot find config file ... docfx.json

It means DocFX is looking for a docfx.json file in your current folder, but it doesn‚Äôt exist. The metadata command requires a config file to know what projects to scan and where to put the output.

How to fix

Option 1 ‚Äî Initialize a new DocFX project

From your solution root:

docfx init -q

This will create a docfx_project folder with a docfx.json file. After that, either:

cd docfx_project
docfx metadata

or reference the config file explicitly:

docfx metadata docfx.json

Option 2 ‚Äî Create a docfx.json manually

If you don‚Äôt want the default init structure, create a docfx.json in your project root:

{
  "metadata": [
    {
      "src": [
        { "files": ["*.csproj"] }
      ],
      "dest": "api"
    }
  ],
  "build": {
    "content": [
      { "files": ["articles/**.md"] },
      { "files": ["api/**.yml"] },
      { "files": ["index.md"] }
    ],
    "dest": "_site"
  }
}

Then you can run:

docfx metadata
docfx build

‚úÖ Tip

If your path has spaces (like OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University), wrap paths in quotes when running commands. DocFX usually handles this, but it avoids headaches.

If you want, I can write a ready-to-use docfx.json specifically for your ase-boose-assignment-BradRL project that points to your .csproj and sets up articles and api automatically. This will get you running in one go.

me: code to add to it for this to work ? ChatGPT: Perfect! Since your .csproj is already there, the only thing you need to do to make DocFX generate API docs from your project is enable XML documentation output. DocFX reads the XML comments from your build to generate the metadata.

Here‚Äôs exactly what to add to your .csproj:

Add inside the existing <PropertyGroup>

<GenerateDocumentationFile>true</GenerateDocumentationFile>
<NoWarn>1591</NoWarn>
  • <GenerateDocumentationFile> ‚Üí Tells the compiler to produce an XML file with all your code comments.
  • <NoWarn>1591</NoWarn> ‚Üí Suppresses warnings for missing XML comments (optional but convenient).

So your <PropertyGroup> will look like this:

<PropertyGroup>
  <OutputType>WinExe</OutputType>
  <TargetFramework>net8.0-windows</TargetFramework>
  <Nullable>enable</Nullable>
  <UseWindowsForms>true</UseWindowsForms>
  <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
  <GenerateDocumentationFile>true</GenerateDocumentationFile>
  <NoWarn>1591</NoWarn>
</PropertyGroup>

After that

  1. Rebuild your project so the XML file is created:
dotnet build

You should see a .xml file next to your .exe or .dll in bin/Debug/net8.0-windows.

  1. Then generate DocFX metadata:
docfx metadata
  1. Build the site:
docfx build
docfx serve _site

You‚Äôll now have a full documentation site with your API reference included.

If you want, I can write the exact docfx.json that points to your .csproj and sets up articles, API, and homepage ready to go for your project folder. It would save you a few manual steps.

me: docfx metadata No files are found with glob pattern **/*.csproj, excluding , under directory "C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\BradleyLeach_BooseApp" warning: No .NET API project detected. Creating output... warning: No .NET API detected for .

Build succeeded with warning.

2 warning(s)
0 error(s)

ChatGPT: Ah! Now the issue is clear ‚Äî the error message is showing that DocFX cannot find your .csproj file because the path in your docfx.json is wrong. Notice this part of your error:

under directory "C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\BradleyLeach_BooseApp"

It‚Äôs duplicating your folder path. This usually happens when the files or cwd in docfx.json is set incorrectly.

‚úÖ How to fix it

  1. Find the exact location of your .csproj. For example, let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs here:
C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\BradleyLeach_BooseApp\BradleyLeach_BooseApp.csproj
  1. Update your docfx.json metadata section to point to it relative to the docfx_project folder:

Assuming your docfx_project folder is at:

C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\docfx_project

Use:

{
  "metadata": [
    {
      "src": [
        { "files": ["../BradleyLeach_BooseApp/BradleyLeach_BooseApp.csproj"] }
      ],
      "dest": "api"
    }
  ],
  "build": {
    "content": [
      { "files": ["articles/**.md"] },
      { "files": ["api/**.yml"] },
      { "files": ["index.md"] }
    ],
    "dest": "_site"
  }
}
  1. Run commands from docfx_project folder:
docfx metadata
docfx build
docfx serve _site

You should now see API documentation generated.

üí° Tip:

  • Always make files relative to the docfx_project folder.
  • Avoid absolute paths; if you do use them, make sure they‚Äôre correctly escaped in JSON (\\ in Windows paths).

me: modift this with those changes { "$schema": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docfx/main/schemas/docfx.schema.json", "metadata": [ { "src": [ { "src": "../C:\Users\mrble\OneDrive - Leeds Beckett University\University Files\Year-3\ASE\ase-boose-assignment-BradRL\BradleyLeach_BooseApp", "files": [ "/*.csproj" ] } ], "dest": "api" } ], "build": { "content": [ { "files": [ "/*.{md,yml}" ], "exclude": [ "_site/" ] } ], "resource": [ { "files": [ "images/" ] } ], "output": "_site", "template": [ "default", "modern" ], "globalMetadata": { "_appName": "BooseApp", "_appTitle": "BooseApp", "_enableSearch": true, "pdf": true } } } ChatGPT: Ah! That warning explains exactly what‚Äôs happening:

../ is currently not supported in glob pattern, please use ../ in src option instead.

DocFX doesn‚Äôt allow ../ in the files glob, only in the "src" folder itself. In other words:

  • files should be just the filename or pattern inside the folder.
  • src should point to the folder containing the .csproj.

Here‚Äôs how to fix your docfx.json:

{
  "$schema": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docfx/main/schemas/docfx.schema.json",
  "metadata": [
    {
      "src": [
        {
          "src": "../BradleyLeach_BooseApp",
          "files": [
            "BradleyLeach_BooseApp.csproj"
          ]
        }
      ],
      "dest": "api"
    }
  ],
  "build": {
    "content": [
      {
        "files": [
          "**/*.{md,yml}"
        ],
        "exclude": [
          "_site/**"
        ]
      }
    ],
    "resource": [
      {
        "files": [
          "images/**"
        ]
      }
    ],
    "output": "_site",
    "template": [
      "default",
      "modern"
    ],
    "globalMetadata": {
      "_appName": "BooseApp",
      "_appTitle": "BooseApp",
      "_enableSearch": true,
      "pdf": true
    }
  }
}

‚úÖ Key change:

"src": "../BradleyLeach_BooseApp",
"files": [
  "BradleyLeach_BooseApp.csproj"
]
  • src points to the folder containing the .csproj.
  • files is the name of the .csproj file inside that folder.
  • No ../ in files.

After saving, run inside docfx_project:

docfx metadata
docfx build
docfx serve _site

This should finally generate your API docs.

If you want, I can also give you a version that automatically detects all .csproj files in subfolders, so you won‚Äôt have to manually change docfx.json if you add projects later.

Do you want me to do that?
